description: The house they wanted was halfway between relaxed and formal, with plenty of room for parents and friends. What they bought was far from it.
title: Mixing Generations and Styles in the Hamptons
title_page: Mixing Generations and Styles in the Hamptons - The New York Times
text:
In 2016, after seven years in the San Francisco Bay Area, Ian Ferguson returned to his native New York with the intention of putting down roots. A big part of the plan involved finding a weekend house in the Hamptons where he could spend some serious time not only with his soon-to-be husband, Ryan James Brandau, after a longtime cross-country relationship, but also with his parents, who live on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
“Call it my guilt of abandoning the East Coast for a decade,” said Mr. Ferguson, 34, who runs Res Facta, a creative agency for tech start-ups, and helped create Tech for Campaigns, an organization focused on helping Democratic political campaigns.
Mr. Brandau, 37, a conductor, was just as keen. “Both Ian’s dad and I love to cook,” he said. “We have very functional kitchens in the city, but not one where we can cook as a team.”
Image “We had never owned a house before and were somewhat intimidated by what that entailed: the machines, the roof, the systems,” said Ian Ferguson, left, at home with Ryan James Brandau. Credit Joe Fletcher
In the Hamptons, they envisioned creating a kitchen “where the four of us could all hang out together while preparing food,” he said.
